channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Zelensky Celebrates Support for Ukraine’s Path to E.U.
item.description: On a day of full-throated political support from Europe, Ukrainian leaders still warn that weapons are what they need to stave off Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: In Ukraine, Some Ethnic Hungarians Feel Ambivalence About the War
item.description: After Moscow’s invasion, some Ukrainians worry that divided loyalties within the country’s small ethnic Hungarian minority might make it susceptible to pro-Russia propaganda from Hungary.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Mezogecse, in the Zakarpattia Region, the Hungarian community celebrated the National Day of Cohesion, marking the anniversary of the Treaty of Trianon, earlier this month.

item.title: As European Leaders Visit Kyiv, Putin Cuts Their Gas Supply
item.description: At a critical moment in the war, Russia is strategically reducing gas flows to drive up prices and hurt European economies already reeling from high inflation.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany and Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy visiting Irpin, near Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Man Confesses to Killing 2 Men Missing in the Amazon, Police Say
item.description: Dom Phillips, a freelance reporter for The Guardian, and Bruno Araújo Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples, had been missing in the Amazon since June 5.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, André Spigariol and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times

item.title: In New Textbooks, Hong Kong Was Never a British Colony
item.description: The books are part of China’s effort to instill a particular historical narrative and to stress patriotic education in a city where a pro-democracy movement was crushed.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at Wong Tai Sin, in Hong Kong, last year. Bejing has launched a sweeping overhaul of the education system in the territory.

item.title: Union Strike in Tunisia Challenges President’s Rule
item.description: The union that called the strike has become the most powerful opponent of President Kais Saied as he tries to concentrate power.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Trade unionists stage a rallied on Thursday during a strike called by the Tunisian General Labor Union in the capital, Tunis.

item.title: Federico Carboni Becomes Italy’s First Assisted Suicide
item.description: The man, Federico Carboni, overcame a series of legal and bureaucratic challenges before ending his life.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: On Thursday, Federico Carboni ended his life, becoming Italy’s first legal assisted suicide.

item.title: Attack on Women in China Stirs Outrage, and Competing Narratives
item.description: Graphic footage of an attack in a restaurant fueled online debate that showed both the growing awareness of women’s rights and how divisive feminism still remains.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video showing two women lying on the ground after being assaulted by a group of men outside a restaurant in the northeastern city of Tangshan, China, in June.

item.title: Kevin Spacey, Accused of Sexual Assault, Appears in British Court
item.description: The proceedings are a rare example of a celebrity #MeToo case leading to criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Kevin Spacey arriving on Thursday at Westminster Magistrates’ Court in London.

item.title: Ryanair Drops South African Passport Test After Protests
item.description: The Irish budget airline had imposed a test in Afrikaans, a language with a racist legacy and that many South Africans don’t speak, to weed out fake documents.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Eligon
item.media:description: A Ryanair aircraft landing at Gatwick Airport in Crawley, Britain, in 2021.

item.title: The TikTok Star and Political Chameleon Vying for Colombia’s Presidency
item.description: Rodolfo Hernández bills himself as a paragon of democracy and a successful businessman who cares for the poor. A trip to Bucaramanga, the mountain-fringed city where he built his empire, reveals a different picture.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:description: The Colombian presidential candidate Rodolfo Hernández, with his wife, Socorro Oliveros, holding the microphone, during a campaign event in Barranquilla, Colombia.

item.title: A Chinese City May Have Used a Covid App to Block Protesters
item.description: People from across China had set off for the city of Zhengzhou to protest the freezing of their savings. Then they were prevented from moving freely.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:description: People scanning QR codes as they prepared to be tested for Covid-19 in Shanghai in March.

item.title: Athens Court Opens Appeals Hearing for Imprisoned Golden Dawn Members
item.description: Dozens of members of the extreme-right party, which was deemed a criminal organization by the Greek judiciary, were convicted in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Members of the far-right Golden Dawn party surrounded by police during appeals proceedings in Athens on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Convicts Palestinian Aid Worker on Charges of Funding Hamas
item.description: Mohammad El Halabi was charged with funneling millions from a Christian charity to the militant group. The charity, World Vision, said there was no evidence to support that and the trial lacked transparency.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Right-wing Israeli protesters, right, arguing with supporters, left, of Mohammad El Halabi, the Gaza director of World Vision, at a district court in the southern Israeli city of Beersheva on Wednesday.

item.title: Fears Grow Over Iran’s Nuclear Program as Tehran Digs a New Tunnel Network
item.description: The conflict over the program is about to flare again as President Biden travels next month to Israel and Saudi Arabia, Iran’s two biggest regional rivals.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: By most accounts, Iran is closer to being able to produce a bomb today than at any other point in the two-decade-long saga of its nuclear program.

item.title: France and Germany Stand With Ukraine, and Putin Can Wait
item.description: Seeking to overcome tensions with Kyiv, President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany backed away from Moscow diplomacy, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: (L-R) President Klaus Iohannis of Romania, Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany hold a news conference after meeting in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Florida Didn’t Preorder Vaccine Doses for Youngest Children, State Says
item.description: It was not immediately clear how much the State Health Department’s decision not to take part in distributing the pediatric shots would impede access to them in Florida in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz and Noah Weiland
item.media:description: Children 5 to 11 years old receiving vaccine shots in November at an elementary school in Miami. Federal regulators are weighing authorization of pediatric vaccine doses for younger children.

item.title: Third American Fighter May Be Missing in Ukraine, State Department Says
item.description: A State Department spokesman did not provide specifics. Earlier reports that two U.S. veterans had been captured by Russian forces remain unconfirmed.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Manuel Balce Ceneta
item.media:description: Ned Price, a U.S. State Department spokesperson, said a possible third American fighter had gone missing in Ukraine in recent weeks.

item.title: Europe Offers Ukraine a Hope of Joining the E.U., but Not a Vast Arsenal
item.description: In their first wartime visit to Kyiv, the leaders of France and Germany countered doubts about their commitment to Ukraine defeating Russia, but did not promise the weapons Ukrainians have called for.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The leaders of Italy, Germany, France and Romania met with President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: European Leaders Travel to Ukraine
item.description: Also, China rewrites Hong Kong’s history textbooks and a Trumpian candidate emerges in Colombia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: From left: Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, French President Emmanuel Macron and Romanian President Klaus Iohannis on Thursday.

item.title: Near Embattled Ukrainian Cities, a Mass Grave for Civilians Grows
item.description: As Russia solidifies control in Sievierodonetsk and shifts its focus to neighboring Lysychansk, civilian casualties there continue to mount.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a mass grave in the hills above the city of Lysychansk, in eastern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: These Polar Bears in Greenland Can Survive With Less Sea Ice
item.description: The overall threat to the animals from climate change remains, but a new finding suggests that small numbers might survive for longer as the Arctic warms.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain

item.title: Little Amal, a Refugee Puppet Who Traveled Europe, Will Visit New York
item.description: Last year, the 12-foot-tall Syrian girl trekked from Turkey to Britain to find her mother. This fall, she’ll visit all five boroughs.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amal, followed by local children, in the coastal city of Calais, France, one of eight countries on last year’s journey.

item.title: Moscow says babies born in occupied Kherson will automatically get Russian citizenship.
item.description: The move, part of an effort to integrate occupied Ukrainian areas with Russia, comes as Kyiv launches counterattacks to try to take back territories.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Kherson, in Ukraine’s south, last month.

item.title: Civilians Are Largely Stranded in Sievierodonetsk, in One of the War’s Deadliest Battles
item.description: People in one city key city are now largely on their own. Those who have escaped describe harrowing scenes.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Marc Santora and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Lysychansk and Sievierodonetsk have seen sustained fighting between Russian and Ukrainian forces for weeks.

item.title: Mass Shootings Are a Reality in Many Communities
item.description: In some communities, shootings are a daily occurrence.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jay Vaughn, in his Englewood neighborhood in Chicago.

item.title: The leaders’ arrival draws a mixed reaction in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in the Kyiv suburb of Irpin on Thursday.

item.title: Macron says European leaders are bringing ‘a message of unity.’
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France arriving at the Kyiv train station on Thursday.

item.title: Draghi, Scholz and Macron face varying challenges on their Ukraine visit.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Katrin Bennhold and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed apartment buildings in Irpin, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: More military aid for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soliders loading artillery in the Donetsk region last month.

item.title: Two Americans Fighting for Ukraine Are Missing, Family Says
item.description: The two men, who are both from Alabama, were last seen in combat on June 9.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub, Maham Javaid and Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Alex Drueke in Tuscaloosa, Ala., in March, before he left for Ukraine.

item.title: In a stadium littered with shrapnel, children’s soccer takes on new meaning.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Tung and Evelina Riabenko
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Olymp Irpin Football Club on Wednesday at the Champion Stadium in Irpin, Ukraine. Debris litters the heavily damaged stands, and explosions left large craters in the field.

item.title: Heading to Ukraine, the Leaders of France and Germany Face a Tense Reception
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany and President Emmanuel Macron of France have had strained relations with Ukraine’s leaders since Russia invaded, struggling to balance support for Kyiv with the rising economic costs of the war.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian artillery gunners last month reloading while engaged in an exchange with Russian forces four miles away near the village of Vuhledar, in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region.

item.title: Urban Artillery Battle in Ukraine Sends Civilians Running in the East
item.description: Heavy volleys between Russian forces taking control of Sievierodonetsk and Ukrainian forces in a neighboring city are leaving wreckage and growing desperation for the residents stuck there.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in Lysychansk, across a river from the embattled city of Sievierodonetsk in eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: $1 Billion to Ukraine
item.description: Plus the Fed raised interest rates and a video of an assault in China went viral.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents line up for humanitarian assistance provided by a German NGO in the town of Irpin, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. and Allies Pledge Additional Arms for Ukraine, but Kyiv Wants More
item.description: Some NATO countries are wary of sending heavy weapons, hoping for a negotiated truce, but the alliance insists publicly that it is committed to helping Ukraine defeat Russia.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III, left, and Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, speaking at a NATO ministers’ meeting on Wednesday in Brussels.

item.title: Billions of Dollars Laundered Annually in British Columbia
item.description: Government officials in the province of British Columbia were aware that suspicious money was entering their revenue stream, but took insufficient steps to stop it.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter, Vjosa Isai and Tracy Sherlock
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A worker cleaning windows at a hotel and casino in Vancouver, British Columbia. A new government report says that billions of dollars a year have been laundered in British Columbia by criminals, using tactics such as gambling in casinos.

item.title: With Northern Ireland and Migrants, Johnson Swings Cudgel of Survival Politics
item.description: Critics say the British leader’s hardened stances on Northern Ireland and immigration are cynical pandering to the pro-Brexit Tories he needs to stay in power.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain at a news conference in Blackpool earlier this month.

item.title: What’s to Come in Russia’s Fight for Sievierodonetsk in Ukraine’s East
item.description: The United Nations says that hundreds of civilians are trapped with besieged Ukrainian forces at a chemical plant and “are suffering and experiencing constant shelling and bombardment.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Civilians in April outside of the Azot chemical plant’s bomb shelter in Sievierodonetsk, where they had been hiding from shelling since the beginning of the war.

item.title: Monkeypox Outbreak Poses ‘Real Risk’ to Public Health, W.H.O. Official Says
item.description: Dr. Hans Kluge, the organization’s director for Europe, said that the longer the virus circulated, the wider its reach would be.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
item.media:description: A sample to be tested for monkeypox at a lab in La Paz University Hospital, Madrid, this month. Europe has emerged as the epicenter of the outbreak.

item.title: From the Wreckage of Caribbean Migration, a New Kind of Beauty
item.description: Four artists created stories of resilience from the traumatic histories of ancestors, on view at the Ford Foundation Gallery.
item.dc:creator: Aruna D’Souza
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andil Gosine, curator of the exhibition “Everything Slackens in a Wreck” at the Ford Foundation, which showcases the work of artists of Asian-Caribbean origin.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Eases Some Covid Precautions Before the Hajj
item.description: Even as coronavirus cases rise steadily, the kingdom has announced the lifting of most Covid precautions as it prepares to receive roughly a million Muslim pilgrims.
item.dc:creator: Nada Rashwan
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims arrive at Saudi Arabia’s King Abdulaziz International Airport in Jeddah on June 5.

item.title: Ukraine has only a fraction of the weapons it needs from the West, a Kyiv official says.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers performing maintenance on an American-made Howitzer last month in the Donetsk region of Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Defense Secretary Urges Allies to Increase Military Aid to Ukraine
item.description: After announcing a major new wave of long-range weaponry for Ukraine, Western leaders will turn their sights toward other potential threats to NATO from Russia and China.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Michael D. Shear and Dan Bilefsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Can a Law Protecting Endangered Animals Stop New Oil Drilling?
item.description: Environmentalists say the government failed to study the threats to endangered species from climate change before issuing oil and gas drilling permits.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A critically endangered Hawaiian monk seal rested on an Oahu beach in Hawaii.

item.title: In Call With Putin, China’s Xi Offers Closer Cooperation with Russia
item.description: The Chinese government has tried to keep good ties with Moscow while maintaining that it wants to be an impartial broker for peace in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China at a meeting in Beijing in February before the war in Ukraine began.

item.title: U.A.E. Bans ‘Lightyear,’ Disney Film with Same-Sex Kiss
item.description: The United Arab Emirates banned the animated film, an offshoot of the “Toy Story” movies, from its cinemas. Censors in Indonesia and Malaysia are also considering restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Alisha Hawthorne, voiced by Uzo Aduba, in a scene from “Lightyear.” The character kisses her wife in one scene, which has prompted restrictions on the film in some countries.

item.title: U.K. Vows to Press Ahead With Deportations to Rwanda
item.description: The government said it would stick with a plan to send asylum seekers to the African country, despite the first flight’s grounding after a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Stephen Castle
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The plane that was to take asylum seekers to Rwanda at an air base in Wiltshire, southern England, on Tuesday. Critics have branded Britain’s policy inhumane and impractical.

item.title: Macron Says He Wants a Ukraine Victory, But Underlines Talks as Necessary
item.description: During a visit to Romania, the French president appeared intent on addressing criticism that he was placing pressure on Kyiv to enter into peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and President Klaus Iohannis of Romania reviewed NATO troops near Constanta, Romania, on Wednesday.

item.title: Constructive Communication Between the U.S. and China Gets Harder
item.description: Later this month, the United States and China may face another threat in their already fraught relations.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Gandel
item.media:credit: Amanda Andrade-Rhoades for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheng Li of the Brookings Institution attends a task force meeting on China during the 2022 New York Times DealBook conference in Washington. At left is Robert Daly, the director of the Kissinger Institute on China.

item.title: Why Doctors Are Divided Over Gender-Affirming Care for Children
item.description: Doctors who provide gender-affirming care are split on how to evaluate teens.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon
item.media:credit: Anne Vetter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tori, 13, told her parents in seventh grade that she didn’t want a boy’s body.

item.title: How the Institute for the Study of War tries to provide a clearer picture of the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Yana Dlugy
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Space sensors can detect heat from artillery strikes.

item.title: NATO’s leader pledges more military aid as Ukraine says weapons are slow to arrive.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: While some American-made howitzers and other NATO-provided heavy weapons have arrived to the country, Ukrainian officials have pressed for speedier delivery of heavy weapons, as well as more sophisticated weaponry.

item.title: Life pauses at a funeral for another soldier killed in the east.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine falters in the east.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volodymyr Prymachenko was buried at Lukyanivsky Military Cemetery. Mr. Prymachenko was killed on June 5th, near Bakhmut in the Donetsk region of Ukraine.

item.title: Search for Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira Becomes a Homicide Investigation
item.description: The police arrested a second suspect after Dom Phillips, a British journalist, and Bruno Araújo Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous people, went missing.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol, Ana Ionova and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Indigenous people helping Navy personnel in the search for the Indigenous expert Bruno Pereira and the freelance British journalist Dom Phillips on Tuesday in Atalaia do Norte, Amazonas State, Brazil.
